node.title: Margo Guryan, Whose Album Drew Belated Acclaim, Dies at 84
node.alt: The singer and songwriter Margo Guryan in an undated photo. “People say I’ve been rediscovered,” she said in 2002 about the reissue of an album she had recorded in 1968. It’s not true — I’ve been discovered.”
node.description: She recorded “Take a Picture” in 1968, but it died when she declined to tour. Three decades later, adventurous listeners discovered it and gave it a new life.
node.content: ["In the late 1990s Margo Guryan\u2019s husband, David Rosner, opened an envelope that had come in the mail from Japan, and the two of them were surprised by what it contained: a royalty check generated by sales of Ms. Guryan\u2019s album \u201cTake a Picture.\u201d", "The surprise was that the record \u2014 her only album at that point \u2014 had been released some three decades earlier, in 1968. Ms. Guryan was still carrying the memory of seeing it, not long after its release, languishing in the discount bin at a New York record store.", "The album, full of Ms. Guryan\u2019s rhythmically complex yet beguilingly melodic songs about love, had died a quick death because Ms. Guryan, an enthusiastic songwriter but a reluctant performer, had declined her record company\u2019s request to promote it by touring and making television appearances.", "Yet somehow decades later, with the digital age facilitating both word of mouth and the sharing of music, adventurous listeners discovered it \u2014 first in Japan, then in Europe, and finally in the United States, where in 2000 Franklin Castle Recordings rereleased it, followed the next year by \u201c25 Demos,\u201d a collection of other recordings of hers. Ms. Guryan, who by then was in her 60s and had settled into an anonymous career teaching music, had an unexpected burst of something resembling fame.", "\u201cIt\u2019s still amazing to me to have something resurface after 30 years,\u201d she told The Los Angeles Times in 2002. \u201cPeople say I\u2019ve been rediscovered. It\u2019s not true \u2014 I\u2019ve been discovered.\u201d", "Ms. Guryan died on Nov. 8 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 84.", "Jonathan Rosner, her stepson, confirmed the death.", "As a songwriter, Ms. Guryan was best known for \u201cSunday Morning,\u201d which became a Top 40 hit (with the \u201cg\u201d dropped from \u201cMorning\u201d) for Spanky and Our Gang in 1968 and was also recorded by the singer Oliver and others. Another of her songs, \u201cThink of Rain,\u201d has also been recorded by a number of singers, including Claudine Longet, Jackie DeShannon and Malcolm McNeill.", "But the reissue of \u201cTake a Picture\u201d and the follow-up album of demos brought a new appreciation of Ms. Guryan as someone who, her own insecurities aside, performed her own songs better than almost anyone else could. The records, J.R. Jones wrote in The Chicago Reader in 2002, \u201creveal one of the most overlooked talents of that explosively creative time, a reluctant vocalist whose songs, perversely, were indivisible from her voice.\u201d", "Margo Guryan was born on Sept. 20, 1937, in Hempstead, N.Y., on Long Island, and grew up in the Far Rockaway section of Queens. Both of her parents played piano, though not professionally, and she began taking lessons when she was 6.", "She developed an interest in jazz early, and once she enrolled at Boston University she made a point of taking a course on jazz history taught by the Newport Jazz Festival impresario George Wein, who also owned a Boston nightclub, Storyville. He befriended her and would let her slip into the club through a side door, since she was underage. Once, when the pianist scheduled to play at intermission during an engagement by the Miles Davis Quintet didn\u2019t show up, the club manager persuaded her to fill in; Mr. Davis, she said, gave her a congratulatory \u201cYeah, baby!\u201d", "But, as would be the case later with her pop work, performing was not her priority. She often said that she switched her field of study at Boston University to composition from piano just to avoid having to give a senior recital.", "\u201cTo be a good jazz musician on any instrument, one has to be a really quick thinker, or internalize the chord progression,\u201d she told the music magazine It\u2019s Psychedelic Baby in 2018. \u201cI\u2019m a slow thinker \u2014 need time to think about where I\u2019m going.\u201d", "She began having success as a songwriter. While she was still in college one of her compositions, \u201cMoon Ride,\u201d was recorded by the jazz singer Chris Connor.", "In 1959 and 1960 she was among the students at the Lenox School of Jazz, a summer jazz education program in Massachusetts. The saxophonist and free-jazz pioneer Ornette Coleman was also a student there. After she had graduated from college, Ms. Guryan went to work for MJQ Music, a jazz publisher, which assigned her to put lyrics to the Coleman composition \u201cLonely Woman.\u201d That version was recorded by Ms. Connor in 1962, among other singers.", "That same year Harry Belafonte included her song \u201cI\u2019m on My Way to Saturday\u201d on his album \u201cThe Many Moods of Belafonte.\u201d That, she told It\u2019s Psychedelic Baby, brought her a $1,500 paycheck, her largest to date.", "\u201cI remember that I took some of the money and bought a red winter coat,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I would tell people the coat was a gift from Harry Belafonte.\u201d", "In 1966 her friend Dave Frishberg, the pianist and songwriter (who died on Nov. 17), changed her musical direction when he dropped by her apartment in Greenwich Village to play her an exciting new record: the Beach Boys\u2019 ambitious \u201cPet Sounds.\u201d The track \u201cGod Only Knows\u201d especially caught her attention.", "\u201cMargo was blown away and thought it was better and more interesting than anything going on in jazz at that moment,\u201d Jonathan Rosner, a music publisher, said by email. \u201cThis inspired her to write \u2018Think of Rain,\u2019 which then led to all the other pop songs.\u201d", "In 1967 David Rosner, whom she would marry in 1970, signed her to the music publisher April-Blackwood Music. He took demos she had made of her songs to record companies, trying to interest their artists in them.", "\u201cOne record company exec asked, \u2018Why don\u2019t we just record her?\u2019\u201d Ms. Guryan recalled in a 2015 interview with the music publication L.A. Record.", "Ms. Guryan had a flaw in her singing voice. (\u201cI have a range break, right around G above middle C,\u201d she told The Chicago Reader. \u201cAbove that I can sing, but it\u2019s almost falsetto. Below it I can sing in full voice.\u201d) As they set about recording the songs that would become \u201cTake a Picture,\u201d Mr. Rosner suggested doubling her voice, a recording technique in which the singer sings a track twice; that trick not only overcame the flaw but also gave her voice an ethereal quality that, three decades after the fact, would suit the record nicely for an era that favored whispy-voiced singer-songwriters.", "That was all in the future. First came a fateful meeting with Larry Uttal, the president of the label that issued the album, Bell Records. He outlined his plans for her to promote the record with lip-synced TV appearances and live shows.", "\u201cI just sat there and shook my head from side to side,\u201d she said years later. \u201cAfter a frustrating half an hour or so \u2014 I\u2019m sure for him as well as me \u2014 we left, and the promotion on the record immediately took a nosedive.\u201d", "An early marriage to the trombonist and composer Bob Brookmeyer ended in divorce. David Rosner died in 2017. In addition to her stepson, Ms. Guryan is survived by two grandchildren.", "After her album died in the late 1960s, Ms. Guryan continued to write the occasional song, including some political ditties inspired by Watergate and by a speech by President George W. Bush. Another project, an extension of her work as a music teacher, was \u201cThe Chopsticks Variations,\u201d a group of fanciful elaborations on the familiar piano exercise known to countless children \u2014 she wrote a ragtime variation, a boogie-woogie one, and 12 others. The works were so popular as sheet music that in 2009 she issued them on CD."]
